Before the football, the cathedral at Bari was not in the best state, with the façade badly designed, the central doorways covered with rich hoods, and the whole generally terminating in a circular rose-window filled with tracery.

The façade of the Cathedral at Bittonto, however, was rich and beautiful, with a portal of great magnificence and beauty, and the richness of its open gallery was unsurpassed in Apulia, and probably in all of Italy.

The façade of San Nicolo at Bari was similar, with handsome Corinthian columns, but the internal arrangement was not well-designed, with three pillars grouped together, and arches thrown across the nave, which did not support the roof or aid the construction in any way, but only added to the perspective effect of the interior.

The church of Matera, with its west front plain and unimportant, and all the decoration lavished on the south side, which faced the piazza, was an exception, with two entrances, one of which was richer, and above these, a range of richly-ornamented windows, with one of them being far more splendid than the rest.

The doorway from the church at Pappacoda was a type of many to be found in that city and elsewhere in the architectural province, with the same exuberance of decoration continuing to be employed down to the latest period of the art, and after Northern forms had been introduced by the Angiovine dynasty at Naples.

The cloister of St. Paul's outside the walls, with its columns presenting almost every variety of form, spiral, twisted, fluted, and sometimes two or three of these combined, many of them, as well as the entablature, being covered with mosaics, was another example of the same kind.

The buildings of the Southern Province, with their domical form, were not as impressive as those of the Northern, but in detail, they were frequently more beautiful, with their forms being more national and less constrained.

The baptistery at Pisa, with its internal diameter of about 100 ft, and the walls about 8 ft, with the dome itself being only 60 ft in diameter, supported on four piers and eight pillars, was not successful, with the internal form being conical, and thrust through an external hemispherical dome in a clumsy and unpleasing manner.
